characters.name: Peter
lines: Hey Stewie, ever wonder why your headphones talk to your phone without cables? Itâ€™s all thanks to Bluetooth, the invisible friend that connects devices like a clingy ghost!

characters.name: Stewie
lines: Ah, Bluetooth, the magic that lets my phone and speakers have a secret conversation. How do they chat without getting tangled up in wires?

characters.name: Peter
lines: Bluetooth uses radio waves to create a personal area network. It's like a tiny, invisible bridge that lets devices send data back and forth, but without the drama of tangled cords.

characters.name: Stewie
lines: So it's like a mini Wi-Fi party, but with fewer guests and less lag? How do devices know when to connect?

characters.name: Peter
lines: Exactly! Devices have to be 'paired' first, like setting up a playdate. Once paired, they remember each other, so they can reconnect automatically.

characters.name: Stewie
lines: And all this happens while I pretend to be productive in class? What are the limits of this tiny radio wave party?

characters.name: Peter
lines: Well, Bluetooth has a range of about 30 feet, so if you wander too far, your music cuts off, like a DJ who just ghosted the party.

characters.name: Stewie
lines: Guess even technology has its boundaries! I'm impressed, but also slightly jealous of my phone's social life.
